author: OfficerCollins
body:
They already ruled (EDIT: ok not ruled, came to a conclusion) all four to be monopolies and are drafting their proposals for moving forward. They will likely not get broken up you are right about that. The breakup of ma bell was a failure beyond compare and some of the committee members were part of the antitrust probe. 

Bezos directly admitted that if they broke up Amazon they would change nothing about the fundamentals of the company and that nothing about its business would change. 

I bet they just fine them a ton and make them pay their competitors like they did with Microsoft in the 90s and more recently with the labor antitrust suit where ed catmull got a slap on the wrist for leading a wage fixing ring and other crimes.

author: solidmussel
body:
Buffet has tons of winners other than apple.

Visa, Mastercard,  American express, verisign, Amazon,  costco, kroger. 

But the biggest position by far is Apple at 134bn.  His whole portfolio is 260bn.  So that seems like a win

author: Wearahat02
body:
I hold a lot of NVDA, it is my best performing stock

I’m not sure what to expect from gaming revenues. While I’m personally excited and will be upgrading my pc at the earliest chance, I am not sure how their gaming revenues will be impacted.

If I put my investor cap on, NVDA should know that their new graphics card would be released in September which means next quarters results includes the sales of that card and future quarters.

They guided to 4.4bn revenue which would account for ampere release which is up from 3.86 this qtr. however I expected more from NVDA with a new graphics card and data center growth expectations. 

Still I think nvda is great even at this price
If they can eventually rake in 20bn annually, they’re not far off, at 65% margin and 4.5-5bn opex then they can achieve 8bn ebit not too far into the future

that’s 43 times pre tax earnings and I think their growth runway is long so that figure should come down over the years

I would say even 50x-60x forward earnings is fine due to how expensive other companies are.

I’m more optimistic on their growth than fang stocks and ma/v.

Yet ma is trading at almost 50 times and visa almost 40 times. Msft, aapl, fb and goog are approaching 40x

Nvda deserves the 100x

I would go:
66% into VOO/SPY, 33% cash (you will need it for future DCA’s or if good stocks dips)

Good stocks for me = strong blue chips (MSFT, AAPL, JPM,  JNJ, V, MA etc)

author: CannonballUnder26
body:
I’d propose two case studies for a general idea: Ma Bell and Microsoft IE. With Ma Bell, they split the company into several regional baby bells. I think you could possibly see this happen with Amazon and Facebook, but I think it’s unlikely to happen to the others. Anyway, this action was not catastrophic for the telecom sector. If anything, the breakup of the monopoly enabled innovation and increased the TAM of telecom companies. If it was just Ma Bell in town, think how long they would’ve resisted DSL or cable internet and tried to keep us all on dialup.


With IE, the problem was that they used their platform (Windows) to monopolize the browser space. I think there’s an extremely compelling case to argue that Google and Apple will be in trouble with this and be forced to spin off their app stores, but this will not cripple them — the vast majority of revenue does not come from App Store monopolies. Microsoft stock has been on a rampage since then, as well.

TLDR: long term investors should not fear antitrust action under current regulations.

body:
I moved 5% to VXX today. Looks like it might move above its 200 MA.  And election results will provide some volatility to sell it higher.  

Or have some cash 5 to 10% on the sideline to gobble up stocks if they drop.  It will be short lived if see a 3 to 10% correction.

author: WolfOctober
body:
The fact that you made this post signals to me that even your gut is telling you that it's risky to having an entirely tech portfolio. 

It never hurts to diversify. 

Don't get me wrong, every company in your portfolio is doing well (even a meme stock like TSLA) right now but that could change very quickly (see TSLA). As one of the unlucky people who bought into the TSLA hype too late, I'm kicking myself.

Can't hurt to throw some ETFs in there to mitigate risk and further diversify. Throw in some financial stocks and some of the bigger healthcare or retail players too while you're at it.

VOO, ABT, COST, NKE, V, MA, PYPL, and HD have all treated me very well these past few months

author: nycgarbage
body: And then what? We push TSLA P/E ratios to 2000+? Lol... The market in June and the market today aren't even remotely similar. You just had a massive rotation/re-balancing of portfolios happen in the last 3 days. Index's are less tech weighted. Look at this board. Today just wiped a massive chunk of speculators fuel right out of the market. Poof. We had STIMULUS in June. The only thing that "could" happen is this market downturn could influence congress into passing the stimulus bill. There is a massive amount of ground to cover to the downside before we regain our 200 day MA. It's time to diversify, set stop losses or learn to use options as they were meant to be used as a fucking hedge.

author: Smitehz
body:
A few things. The unemployment announcement was better than expected which hurts the argument for another stimulus round.  

SPY hit the 200 day Bollinger band top (+2.5 SD above the 200 MA) which is too high (this in itself doesn't always cause a pull back but it definitely can). 

Trump tweeted about how good things are so the MM moved money out to help argue for more stimulus money.  (this won't last long cause equities besides tesla are the best place to keep money right now) 

Google may be in for an antitrust suit.
